queries.query_text: Summarize PERCEPTION AND  DETECTION
queries.query_text_short: Summarize PERCEPTION AND  DETECTION

queries.query_text: Summarize Your Perception measures your ability to notice things, search for what's hidden, and tell whether  something about a situation is suspicious.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize Your Perception measures your ability to notice things, search for what's hidden

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Perception is frequently used for rolling initiative in an  encounter, and for the Seek action. See page 396 for the  procedure for rolling a Perception check.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Perception is frequently used for rolling initiative in an  encounter, and for t?

queries.query_text: Summarize LIGHT
queries.query_text_short: Summarize LIGHT

queries.query_text: Summarize There are three levels of light: bright light, dim light, and  darkness. The rules in this book assume that all creatures are  in bright light unless otherwise noted. A source of light lists  the radius in which it sheds bright light, and it sheds dim light  to double that radius.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize There are three levels of light: bright light, dim light, and  darkness. The rul

queries.query_text: Summarize BRIGHT LIGHT
queries.query_text_short: Summarize BRIGHT LIGHT

queries.query_text: Summarize In bright light, such as sunlight, creatures and objects can  be observed clearly by anyone with average vision or better.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize In bright light, such as sunlight, creatures and objects can  be observed clearl

queries.query_text: Summarize DIM LIGHT
queries.query_text_short: Summarize DIM LIGHT

queries.query_text: Summarize Areas in shadow or lit by weak light sources are in dim  light. Creatures and objects in dim light have the concealed  condition, unless the seeker has darkvision or low-light vision  (page 425), or a precise sense other than vision.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize Areas in shadow or lit by weak light sources are in dim  light. Creatures and ob

queries.query_text: Summarize DARKNESS
queries.query_text_short: Summarize DARKNESS

queries.query_text: Summarize A creature or object within darkness is hidden or undetected  unless the seeker has darkvision or a precise sense other  than vision. A creature without darkvision or another means  of perceiving in darkness has the blinded condition while in  darkness, though it might be able to see illuminated areas beyond  the darkness. If a creature can see into an illuminated area, it can  observe creatures within that illuminated area normally. After  being in darkness, sudden exposure to bright light might make  you dazzled for a short time, as determined by the GM.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize A creature or object within darkness is hidden or undetected  unless the seeker

queries.query_text: Summarize SENSES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize SENSES

queries.query_text: What is the rule about The ways a creature can use Perception depend on what  senses it has. The primary concepts you need to know for  understanding senses are precise senses, imprecise senses,  and the three states of detection a target can be in: observed,  hidden, or undetected. Vision, hearing, and scent are three  prominent senses, but each has a different degree of acuity.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about The ways a creature can use Perception depend on what  senses it has. The primar?

queries.query_text: Summarize PRECISE SENSES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize PRECISE SENSES

queries.query_text: Summarize Average vision is a precise sense—a sense that can be used to  perceive the world in nuanced detail. The only way to target
queries.query_text_short: Summarize Average vision is a precise sense—a sense that can be used to  perceive the worl

queries.query_text: What is the rule about a creature without having drawbacks is to use a precise  sense. You can usually detect a creature automatically with  a precise sense unless that creature is hiding or obscured by  the environment, in which case you can use the Seek basic  action to better detect the creature.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about a creature without having drawbacks is to use a precise  sense. You can usually ?

queries.query_text: Summarize IMPRECISE SENSES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize IMPRECISE SENSES

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Average hearing is an imprecise sense—it can't detect the  full range of detail that a precise sense can. You can usually  sense a creature automatically with an imprecise sense, but  it has the hidden condition instead of the observed condition.  It might be undetected by you if it's using Stealth or in an  environment that distorts the sense, such as a noisy room  in the case of hearing. In those cases, you have to use the  Seek basic action to detect the creature. At best, an imprecise  sense can be used to make an undetected creature (or one  you didn't even know was there) merely hidden—it can't make  the creature observed.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Average hearing is an imprecise sense—it can't detect the  full range of detail ?

queries.query_text: Summarize VAGUE SENSES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize VAGUE SENSES

queries.query_text: What is the rule about A character also has many vague senses—ones that can alert  you that something is there but aren't useful for zeroing in on  it to determine exactly what it is. The most useful of these  for a typical character is the sense of smell. At best, a vague  sense can be used to detect the presence of an unnoticed  creature, making it undetected. Even then, the vague sense  isn't sufficient to make the creature hidden or observed.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about A character also has many vague senses—ones that can alert  you that something i?

queries.query_text: Summarize When one creature might detect another, the GM almost  always uses the most precise sense available.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize When one creature might detect another, the GM almost  always uses the most prec

queries.query_text: Summarize SPECIAL SENSES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize SPECIAL SENSES

queries.query_text: Summarize While a human might have a difficult time making creatures  out in dim light, an android can see those creatures just fine.  And though androids have no problem seeing on a dimly  lit street, their vision can't penetrate complete darkness,  whereas a pahtra's can. Special senses allow a creature to  ignore or reduce the effects of the undetected, hidden, or  concealed conditions (described on pages 425–426) when it  comes to situations that foil average vision.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize While a human might have a difficult time making creatures  out in dim light, an

queries.query_text: Summarize DARKVISION AND GREATER  DARKVISION
queries.query_text_short: Summarize DARKVISION AND GREATER  DARKVISION

queries.query_text: Summarize A creature with darkvision or greater darkvision can see  perfectly well in areas of darkness and dim light, though
queries.query_text_short: Summarize A creature with darkvision or greater darkvision can see  perfectly well in area

queries.query_text: What is the rule about such vision is in black and white only. Some forms of magical  darkness, such as a 4th-rank *darkness* spell, block normal  darkvision. A creature with greater darkvision, however, can  see through even these forms of magical darkness.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about such vision is in black and white only. Some forms of magical  darkness, such as?

queries.query_text: Summarize LOW-LIGHT VISION
queries.query_text_short: Summarize LOW-LIGHT VISION

queries.query_text: Summarize A creature with low-light vision can see in dim light as though  it were bright light, so it ignores the concealed condition due  to dim light.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize A creature with low-light vision can see in dim light as though  it were bright

queries.query_text: Summarize SCENT
queries.query_text_short: Summarize SCENT

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Scent involves sensing creatures or objects by smell, and is  usually a vague sense. The range is listed in the ability, and it  functions only if the creature or object being detected emits  an aroma. If a creature emits a heavy aroma or is upwind, the  GM can double or even triple the range of scent abilities used  to detect that creature, and the GM can reduce the range if a  creature is downwind.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Scent involves sensing creatures or objects by smell, and is  usually a vague se?

queries.query_text: Summarize TREMORSENSE
queries.query_text_short: Summarize TREMORSENSE

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Tremorsense allows a creature to feel the vibrations through  a solid surface caused by movement. It's usually an imprecise  sense with a limited range (listed in the ability). Tremorsense  functions only if the detecting creature is on the same surface  as the subject, and only if the subject is moving along (or  burrowing through) the surface.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Tremorsense allows a creature to feel the vibrations through  a solid surface ca?

queries.query_text: Summarize DETECTING CREATURES
queries.query_text_short: Summarize DETECTING CREATURES

queries.query_text: Summarize Three conditions measure the degree to which you can sense  a creature: observed, hidden, and undetected. However, the  concealed and invisible conditions can partially mask a  creature, and the unnoticed condition indicates you have no  idea a creature is around. You can find these conditions in  the Conditions Appendix on pages 435–441.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize Three conditions measure the degree to which you can sense  a creature: observed

queries.query_text: Summarize With the exception of invisible, these conditions are  relative to the viewer—it's possible for a creature to be  observed to you but hidden from your ally. Most of these  rules apply to objects as well as creatures.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize With the exception of invisible, these conditions are  relative to the viewer—it

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Typically, the GM tracks how well creatures detect each  other since neither party has perfect information. For  example, you might think a creature is in the last place  you sensed it, but it was able to Sneak away. Or you  might think a creature can't see you in the dark, but it has  darkvision.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Typically, the GM tracks how well creatures detect each  other since neither par?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about You can attempt to avoid detection by using the Stealth  skill (page 207) to Avoid Notice, Hide, or Sneak, or by using  Deception to Create a Diversion (page 198).?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about You can attempt to avoid detection by using the Stealth  skill (page 207) to Avo?

queries.query_text: Summarize OBSERVED
queries.query_text_short: Summarize OBSERVED

queries.query_text: What is the rule about In most circumstances, you can sense creatures without  difficulty and target them normally. Creatures in this state  are observed. Observing requires a precise sense, which for  most creatures means sight. If you can't observe the creature,  it's either hidden, undetected, or unnoticed, and you'll need  to factor in the targeting restrictions. Even if a creature is  observed, it might still be concealed.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about In most circumstances, you can sense creatures without  difficulty and target th?

queries.query_text: Summarize **DETECTING WITH OTHER SENSES**
queries.query_text_short: Summarize **DETECTING WITH OTHER SENSES**

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Most abilities that designate "a creature you can see"  or the like function just as well if the user can precisely  sense the subject with a different sense. If a monster  uses a sense other than vision, the GM can adapt ways  of avoiding detection that work with the monster's  senses. For example, a creature that has echolocation  might use hearing as a primary sense. This could mean  its quarry is concealed in a noisy chamber, hidden in  a great enough din, or invisible under a *silence* spell.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Most abilities that designate "a creature you can see"  or the like function jus?

queries.query_text: Summarize **Using Stealth with Other Senses**
queries.query_text_short: Summarize **Using Stealth with Other Senses**

queries.query_text: What is the rule about The Stealth skill is designed to use Hide for avoiding  visual detection and Avoid Notice and Sneak to avoid  being both seen and heard. For many special senses,  a player can describe how they're avoiding detection  by that special sense and use the most applicable  Stealth action. For instance, a creature stepping lightly  to avoid being detected via tremorsense would be using Sneak.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about The Stealth skill is designed to use Hide for avoiding  visual detection and Avo?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about In some cases, rolling a Dexterity-based Stealth  skill check to Sneak doesn't make the most sense.  For example, a PC trying to avoid being detected by  a creature that senses heartbeats might meditate  to slow their heart rate, using Wisdom instead of  Dexterity for their Stealth check. When a creature  could detect you using multiple different senses, use  your lowest applicable attribute modifier.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about In some cases, rolling a Dexterity-based Stealth  skill check to Sneak doesn't m?

queries.query_text: Summarize HIDDEN
queries.query_text_short: Summarize HIDDEN

queries.query_text: What is the rule about A creature that's hidden is only barely perceptible. You only  know what space it occupies. Perhaps the creature just used  the Hide action. Your target might be behind some obstruction,  where you can see some movement but can't determine an  exact location. Maybe you've been blinded or the creature is  invisible, but you used the Seek basic action to determine its  general location based on hearing alone. Regardless of the  specifics, you're off-guard to a hidden creature.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about A creature that's hidden is only barely perceptible. You only  know what space i?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about When targeting a hidden creature, before you roll to  determine your effect, you must attempt a DC 11 flat check.  If you fail, you don't affect the creature, though the actions  you used are still expended—as well as any spell slots, costs,  and other resources. You remain off-guard to the creature,  whether you successfully target it or not.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about When targeting a hidden creature, before you roll to  determine your effect, you?

queries.query_text: Summarize UNDETECTED
queries.query_text_short: Summarize UNDETECTED

queries.query_text: What is the rule about If a creature is undetected, you don't know what space it  occupies and you're off-guard to it. The Seek basic action can  help you find an undetected creature, usually making it hidden  from you instead of undetected. If a creature is undetected,  that doesn't mean you're unaware of its presence—you might  suspect an undetected creature is nearby. The unnoticed  condition covers creatures you're unaware of.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about If a creature is undetected, you don't know what space it  occupies and you're o?

queries.query_text_short: Summarize **CONDITIONS ** **APPENDIX**

queries.query_text: Summarize **GLOSSARY & ** **INDEX**
queries.query_text_short: Summarize **GLOSSARY & ** **INDEX**

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Targeting an undetected creature is difficult. If you suspect  there's a creature around, you can pick a square and attempt  an attack. This works like targeting a hidden creature, but the  flat check and attack roll are both rolled in secret by the GM.  The GM won't tell you why you missed—whether it was due  to failing the flat check, rolling an insufficient attack roll, or  choosing the wrong square. The GM might allow you to try  targeting an undetected creature with some spells or other  abilities in a similar fashion. Undetected creatures are subject  to area effects normally.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Targeting an undetected creature is difficult. If you suspect  there's a creatur?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about For instance, suppose an enemy witchwarper cast  *invisibility* and then Sneaked away. You suspect that with  the witchwarper's Speed of 25 feet, they probably moved 15  feet toward an open door. You move up and attack a space 15  feet from where the witchwarper started and directly on the  path to the door. The GM secretly rolls an attack roll and flat  check, but they know that you weren't quite correct—your foe  was actually in the adjacent space! The GM tells you that you  missed, so you decide to make your next attack on the adjacent  space, just in case. This time, it's the right space, and the GM's  secret attack roll and flat check both succeed, so you hit!?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about For instance, suppose an enemy witchwarper cast  *invisibility* and then Sneaked?

queries.query_text: Summarize UNNOTICED
queries.query_text_short: Summarize UNNOTICED

queries.query_text: Summarize If you have no idea a creature is even present, that creature  is unnoticed by you. A creature that's undetected might also  be unnoticed. This condition usually matters for abilities  that can be used only against targets totally unaware of  your presence.
queries.query_text_short: Summarize If you have no idea a creature is even present, that creature  is unnoticed by y

queries.query_text: What is the rule about A concealed creature is in mist, within dim light, or amid  something else that obscures sight but isn't a physical  barrier. When you target a creature that's concealed  from you, you must attempt a DC 5 flat check before  you roll to determine your effect. If you fail, you don't  affect the target. The concealed condition doesn't change  which of the main categories of detection apply. A  creature in a light fog bank is still observed even though  it's concealed.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about A concealed creature is in mist, within dim light, or amid  something else that ?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about A creature with the invisible condition (by way of an  *invisibility* spell, for example) is automatically undetected  to any creatures relying on sight as their only precise  sense. Precise senses other than sight ignore the invisible  condition. You can Seek (page 409) to attempt to figure out  an invisible creature's location, making it only hidden from  you. This lasts until the invisible creature successfully  uses Sneak to become undetected again. If you're already  observing a creature when it becomes invisible, it starts  out hidden since you know where it was, though it can  then Sneak to become undetected.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about A creature with the invisible condition (by way of an  *invisibility* spell, for?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Other effects might partially foil invisibility. For instance,  if you were tracking an invisible creature's footprints through  the snow, the footprints would make it hidden. Throwing a  net over an invisible creature would make it observed but  concealed for as long as the net is on it.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Other effects might partially foil invisibility. For instance,  if you were trac?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about When every individual action counts, you enter the encounter mode of play. In this mode, time  is divided into rounds, each of which is 6 seconds of time in the game world. Every round, each  participant takes a turn in an established order. During your turn, you can use actions, and depending  on the details of the encounter, you might have the opportunity to use reactions and free actions on  your own turn and on others' turns.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about When every individual action counts, you enter the encounter mode of play. In th?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about An encounter is played out in a series of rounds, during which  the player characters, adversaries, and other participants in the  encounter act in sequence. You roll initiative to determine this  order at the start of the encounter and then play through rounds  until a conclusion is reached and the encounter ends. The rules  in this section assume a combat encounter—a battle—but the  general structure can apply to any kind of encounter. Other  types of encounters, like social encounters, might use longer  rounds or have other modifications to the basic structure.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about An encounter is played out in a series of rounds, during which  the player chara?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about STEP 1: ROLL INITIATIVE?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about STEP 1: ROLL INITIATIVE?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about When the GM calls for it, you'll roll initiative to determine  your place in the initiative order, which is the sequence in  which the encounter's participants will take their turns.  Rolling initiative marks the start of an encounter. More often  than not, you'll roll initiative when you enter a battle.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about When the GM calls for it, you'll roll initiative to determine  your place in the?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Typically, you'll roll a Perception check to determine your  initiative—the more aware you are of your surroundings,  the more quickly you can respond. Sometimes, though, the  GM might call on you to roll some other type of check. For  instance, if you were Avoiding Notice during exploration  (page 430), you'd roll a Stealth check. A social encounter  could call for a Deception or Diplomacy check. In most cases,  you can still use Perception if you prefer.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Typically, you'll roll a Perception check to determine your  initiative—the more?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about The GM rolls initiative for anyone other than the player  characters in the encounter. If these include a number of  identical creatures, the GM could roll once for the group as a  whole and have them take their turns within the group in any  order. However, this can make battles less predictable and more  dangerous, so the GM might want to roll initiative for some or  all creatures individually unless it's too much of a burden.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about The GM rolls initiative for anyone other than the player  characters in the enco?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Unlike a check, where the result is compared to a DC, the  results of initiative rolls are ranked. This ranking sets the  order in which the encounter's participants act—the initiative  order. The character with the highest result goes first. The  second highest follows, and so on until whoever had the  lowest result takes their turn last.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Unlike a check, where the result is compared to a DC, the  results of initiative?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about If your result is tied with an enemy's result, the enemy  goes first. If your result is tied with another PC's, you can  decide between yourselves who goes first when you reach  that place in the initiative order. After that, your places in the?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about If your result is tied with an enemy's result, the enemy  goes first. If your re?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about initiative order usually don't change during the encounter.  (But see the Delay basic action on page 408.)?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about initiative order usually don't change during the encounter.  (But see the Delay ?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about A round begins when the participant with the highest  initiative roll result starts their turn, and it ends when the  one with the lowest initiative ends their turn. The process  of taking a turn is detailed below. Creatures might also act  outside their turns with reactions and free actions.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about A round begins when the participant with the highest  initiative roll result sta?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Once everyone in the encounter has taken a turn, the round  is over and the next one begins. Don't roll initiative again; the  new round proceeds in the same order as the previous one,  repeating the cycle until the encounter ends.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Once everyone in the encounter has taken a turn, the round  is over and the next?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about When your foes are defeated, some sort of truce is reached,  or some other event or circumstance ends the combat, the  encounter is over. You and the other participants no longer  follow the initiative order, and a more free-form style of play  resumes, with the game typically moving into exploration mode.  Sometimes, at the end of an encounter, the GM will award  Experience Points to the party or you'll find treasure to divvy up.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about When your foes are defeated, some sort of truce is reached,  or some other event?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about When it's your turn to act, you can use single actions ([one-action]),  short activities ([two-actions] and [three-actions]), reactions ([reaction]), and free actions  ([free-action]). When you're finished, your turn ends and the character  next in the initiative order begins their turn. Sometimes it's  important to note when during your turn something happens,  so a turn is divided into three steps.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about When it's your turn to act, you can use single actions ([one-action]),  short ac?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about Many things happen automatically at the start of your turn it's a common point for tracking the passage of time for  effects that last multiple rounds. At the start of each of your  turns, take these steps in any order you choose.?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about Many things happen automatically at the start of your turn it's a common point f?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about • If you created an effect lasting for a certain number of  rounds, reduce the number of rounds remaining by 1. The  effect ends if the duration is reduced to 0. For example,  if you cast a spell that lasts 3 rounds on yourself during?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about • If you created an effect lasting for a certain number of  rounds, reduce the n?

queries.query_text: What is the rule about **ANCESTRIES & ** **BACKGROUNDS**?
queries.query_text_short: What is the rule about **ANCESTRIES & ** **BACKGROUNDS**?
